title: Rafael Dudamel
text:
Rafael Édgar Dudamel Ochoa, commonly known as Rafael Dudamel (born January 7, 1973), is a <a href="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>n <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="manager">manager</a>, currently in charge of Colombian club <a href="Deportivo%20Cali">Deportivo Cali</a>, and former player who played as a <a href="Goalkeeper%20%28association%20football%29">goalkeeper</a>. 
As a player, Dudamel made 56 appearances for the <a href="Venezuela%20national%20football%20team">Venezuela national team</a>.
Playing career.
Club.
During his career, Dudamel played for several Venezuelan and <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>n football clubs. Among the Venezuelan clubs are <a href="Universidad%20de%20Los%20Andes%20F%C3%BAtbol%20Club">Universidad de Los Andes</a>, <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20El%20Vig%C3%ADa">El Vigía</a>, , <a href="Uni%C3%B3n%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Maracaibo">UA Maracaibo</a> and <a href="Deportivo%20T%C3%A1chira%20F%C3%BAtbol%20Club">Deportivo Táchira</a>. <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Huila">Atlético Huila</a>, <a href="Independiente%20Santa%20Fe">Independiente Santa Fe</a>, <a href="Deportivo%20Cali">Deportivo Cali</a>, <a href="Millonarios">Millonarios</a> and <a href="Cortulua">Cortulua</a> are the Colombian clubs where he played. He has also played for <a href="Quilmes%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Club">Quilmes</a>, of <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a>. He was transferred to <a href="Mamelodi%20Sundowns%20FC">Mamelodi Sundowns</a>, of <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> in 2005. In 2007 after the Copa America, he transferred to <a href="Am%C3%A9rica%20de%20Cali">América de Cali</a>, a top Colombian club, alongside Venezuelan international <a href="Jorge%20Alberto%20Rojas">Jorge Rojas</a>. He left América and returned to <a href="Estudiantes%20de%20M%C3%A9rida%20F%C3%BAtbol%20Club">Estudiantes de Mérida</a> on August 29, 2008.
International.
As of November 2007, Dudamel has 56 caps and one goal for the <a href="Venezuela%20national%20football%20team">Venezuela national football team</a>. He was capped for the first time in 1993. He scored a direct free kick in the <a href="World%20Cup%201998">World Cup 1998</a> qualifier against Argentina.
Managerial career.
On 18 October 2017 Dudamel is appointed manager of Venezuela’s national football team.
On 5 June 2016 Dudamel gets his first win in an official tournament as national coach with a
1-0 victory over Jamaica in the 2016 Copa America. In his next match at the tournament, he upsets Uruguay 1-0. The winner was scored by Salomon Rondón, who tapped in after a long range attempt by Alejandro Guerra was saved. In the final group match, he drew against Mexico 1-1. In the knockout stages, Venezuela lost immediately, 4-1 to Argentina.
At the 2017 FIFA Under-20 World Cup, Dudamel led the U20s to the final, where they lost to England 1-0 in the final. It was the nation's best ever performance at U20 competition.
On 2 January 2020, he resigned from the Venezuela national team, and four days later signed a two-year contract with Brazilian club <a href="Clube%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Mineiro">Atlético Mineiro</a>. On 27 February 2020, he was sacked by Atlético, following eliminations from the <a href="2020%20Copa%20Sudamericana">Copa Sudamericana</a> and the <a href="2020%20Copa%20do%20Brasil">Copa do Brasil</a>.
He spent time at the Universidad de Chile between 2020-2021, in 2021 he was raised to the command of Deportivo Cali, becoming colombian champion.
